newsitem.title: FRANCE: Western execs see China boom,shrug off HK handover.
newsitem.headline: Western execs see China boom,shrug off HK handover.

text.p: China is expected to become the world's fourth largest advertising market in the next five years and Western-based ad agencies foresee no problems with the Hong Kong handover, an industry xpert said.
Miles Young, the head of Ogilvy & Mather's Asia-Pacific region, told Reuters late on Thursday that China's advertising industry was forecast to grow by a staggering 40 percent per year through 2002.

He said Ogilvy & Mather, a global ad agency owned by London-based WPP Group Plc, the world largest advertising and marketing services group, had strong faith in China's economy and advertising market.
"China is a very deliberate growth manager," Young said in an interview.
He said he did not expect the June 30 handover, when Hong Kong reverts to Chinese rule after 150 years as a British colony, to cause any problems or disruption for advertising agencies.
"As far as we're concerned, there are no concerns whatsoever," said Young, who heads Ogilvy & Mather's Asia operations from its regional office in Hong Kong.
"We have our headquarters in Hong Kong and we intend to stay there," he said.
Young said China's enormous economic growth and liberalisation had provided a backbone for continued progress, and there was no need to fear the trend would be reversed.
"It's gone too far," he said.
The world's biggest advertising market is the United States, followed by Japan, Germany, France and Britain.
But China, with one of the world's fastest-growing consumer groups, will knock France from fourth place if present growth continues.
Young said Singapore and Hong Kong had been Asia's two most important advertising markets until a few years ago, but that had changed.
Along with China, Asia's greatest growth markets for advertising now included India, the Philippines, Indonesia and Malaysia.
Young said Asian economic growth has sparked a growing appetite for consumer goods.
In China, the government's policy of one child per family had had the effect of boosting the amount of disposable income in many households.
Young said the one-child policy had created a generation of so-called "little emperors", children who had powerful clout over purchasing decisions made by parents and grandparents.
He said large privatisation programmes in China were fuelling economic growth and spurring many companies to adapt Western-style marketing and branding techniques.
Western-based ad agencies used to get most of their business in Asia by creating advertising campaigns for Western-based multinationals.
But Young said Chinese-based companies were the ones driving the growth of advertising in China.
Local companies account for a majority of Ogilvy & Mather's clients in China, including 60 percent in Shanghai and 70 percent in Guangdong.
Young said China was developping big regional consumer markets and that local companies were using advertising to create national brands and reach those geographically-diverse consumers.
He said China's massive size meant ad agencies needed strong networks with offices across the country. They also need big networks to deal with China's huge and diverse media industry
"It's one of the most diverse media markets in the world," he said. "There are hundreds of newspapers, television stations and radio stations."
